SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Solicitor General.
SP.P: If the gentleman is an attorney, as I am told, I should like to know whether he would be suffered to go on in this way in the courts of Westminster-Hall?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: It is certainly not a question sit for the wit∣ness to answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: Have you any mode of distinguishing those papers found in my trunk from those that belonged to Mr. Ge∣rald in the same trunk?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Then it may happen that you may have intermixed a pa∣per of Mr. Gerald's and a paper of mine?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; they were taken down distinctly, and marked with your own initials in your own presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who arranged the papers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I arranged them in your presence; I took them out at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: Did you not say, the Pannel picked out his papers and Mr. Gerald his?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; there was a paper put in, and all below that be∣longed to the Pannel.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did I not observe to you at the time, that being in an inn, we could not be answerable for what papers were found in our room?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I dare say you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did I not say, that even the messenger might bring that paper, if he thought proper, and hustle them into the trunk at once?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: So you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: By what means are you certain, that the papers which you found in Mr. Skirving's possession were minutes of the con∣vention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: From various circumstances; but I submit again to the court, whether it is proper to answer that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: Yes; you must give answers to legal ques∣tions.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The minutes were established to be minutes of the Con∣vention, by some of the members.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You accompanied the Sheriff to Mr. Laing's room.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did I say any thing to you at the time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; you was the first person that called to me, handed me a motion, and desired I would read it; I told him I had no∣thing to do with it: it was a motion to petition the King, or something of that kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect the Sheriff Substitute saying, that he acted by orders?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say; but he certainly told you, he came for the express purpose of dismissing that meeting, and that you must do no business as a British Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did I not speak to you; and you afterwards answered me, that you was doing your duty?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; by attending the Sheriffs.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You say that the meeting ended with prayer; can you recollect that prayer?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Does beginning and closing a meeting, for obtaining a reform in Parliament, with prayer, apply to the word Sedition?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: That is a very improper question.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the petition for the warrant state, that I had met with others in Laing's workshop, that I had been forced from the chair, that we had said that we were assembled for petition∣ing a reform of parliament, and closed with prayer? Was that warrant which took me up then the same as before?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The warrant could not mention it, because the petition was two days before the warrant was obtained; it could not mention that which did not take place for two days afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect the Pannel being brought before you the 5th of December for examination?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he at that time emit a declaration in your presence?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he do it voluntarily, and without compulsion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was he sober, and of sound mind?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you subscribe that declaration?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look and see if that is it.—It is the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Is there any reference in that declaration to a motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there a paper found in the secretary's possession which appeared to be that motion?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you put any mark upon the paper so as to know it again?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; this is it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect any other papers having been produced at that examination or afterwards?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There were no papers produced that day; the next day there were papers taken from a trunk of his, of which an inven∣tory was made, which I identified.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was that trunk brought along with him?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was he asked for the key of that trunk?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; and he declined giving it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there any seal put upon it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not in my presence; I understand there was.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When it was opened the following day, was any inven∣tory made of the contents?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there any papers other than those claimed by the Pannel?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; papers belonging to Mr. Gerald.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were those claimed by the Pannel separated from those claimed by Mr. Gerald?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; and an inventory was made of both, and they ac∣quiesced in both.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: And was it done in their presence?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you subscribe that inventory?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you likewise put any mark upon the articles which it contains?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you compare those articles which have your super∣scription with the articles which are in the inventory?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; it was only those that were relating to the business in hand that were put in the inventory. (Examines and compares them.) They are all marked by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect why Mr. Margarot was liberated?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Upon finding bail.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was the nature of the charge against him for which he was brought before you for examination?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: For seditious practices, as being a member of the meeting calling themselves the British Convention of the Delegates of the Friends of the people.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect to have gone in the execution of your duty to a wright's shop on the south side of the town, the 6th of December, with a view of dispersing this meeting?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Be so obliging to mention to the Court and Jury what passed when you so went to that meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It was on Friday evening, the 6th of December, I went and attended the Lord Provost, with the magistrates of the city; a great number of people were assembled in a wright's shop, and I went immediately up to the table, where I saw some people whose faces I recognized; Mr. Skirving, Mr. Brown, Mr. Margarot, and several others; I asked what the meeting was? I did not get a direct answer; I asked if it was the British Convention? One of the members, and I think it was Mr. Margarot, said that it was; I told him that I was Sheriff Substi∣tute for the county, and that I came there to disperse that meet∣ing, which was an illegal one, upon this some conversation took place; and I think Mr. Margarot was the man who spoke most on account of the Convention; he said, they were met peacea∣bly, that it was a legal Constitutional Meeting, and that they were then met for a petition to Parliament. I told him, that my resolution had been taken before I came there; that I came with a determination to disperse that meeting; that no words were necessary, no argument that they could use could alter my determination: some more conversation took place. Mr. Mar∣garot, finding I was determined upon it, said that he would take the chair, with the approbation of the meeting, which was then empty; accordingly upon this, he was unanimously called to the chair: I think before he took the chair, he said, the meeting would not disperse without force was used; I told him, I hoped it would be unnecessary to use force, but if it was ne∣cessary, I should certainly make use of it. He took the chair, and finding they would not disperse without some force, I took him by the arm, which he considered as force, and he came out of the chair; immediately upon his doing so, Mr. Gerald, another of the gentlemen present, took the chair; I told him I really thought that it was improper that another person should do the same thing, if they were all to take the chair one after another; I hoped they would not think that necessary; however I took the same method of forcing Mr. Gerald from the chair that I did Mr. Margarot: Mr. Gerald then made an extem∣pore prayer, and left the chair. Mr. Margarot, amongst other things that he mentioned, said, the meeting of the Con∣vention had declared themselves permament. I told him it might be so, but I was determined they should not meet within the county where I had a jurisdiction. I think they called out for the gentlemen to disperse, and by degrees they dispersed; and I saw the last person out, and saw the door locked, and took the key.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You said you recognized several persons; among others, the Pannel at the bar, and Mr. Gerald; how came you to recog∣nize the Pannel particularly?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Because he had been before me the night before, and had been examined upon the charge I have already mentioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You had granted bail?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.
SP.STAGE: (Harry Davidson cross examined by Mr. Margarot.)

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How are you sure that the motion which you found in the possession of Mr. Skirving is in my handwriting, as you have declared it to be?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not assert that it was your handwriting, at least I did not mean to say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did I not give one uniform reason for declining to emit a declaration, for refusing to give up the key of my trunk, and for asserting the right of the Convention to meet; did I not say, that the proceedings against them were illegal?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: You cer∣tainly did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did I not ask you, why you would interrupt us in our le∣gal proceedings? and did you not answer me, that you acted according to order? Remember, Sir, that you are upon your oath.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say that I recollect, whether I said by order; as Sheriff substitute of the County, I acted by my own authority; I do not recollect the precise words I may have used, but I was certainly acting as Sheriff of the County.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What could induce you to think that a meeting like that was illegal?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: That is not a proper question.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: It only hinges upon another. Did you see at the time of your entrance there, any confusion, riot, or disorder?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you on the contrary, perceive the business of the even∣ing carried on with regularity?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There was but little business going on after I came in, Mr. Gerald was upon his legs speaking, and I certainly inter∣rupted him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was prayer called for?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It was, I do not know whether it was not you that said it was not usual that the meeting should depart without prayer; and I believe I gave consent that prayer should be made.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: O, you did consent to that? Do you recollect the subject of the debate?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think you, or some other person, put into my hand a small piece of paper, upon which was wrote a petition to Par∣liament, which you said was the subject of the—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: Of the order of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: That the purpose of their meeting was to petition Parlia∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: I hope the order of the day is not an offence, because I believe it is made use of sometimes in the House of Commons.

SP.SPEAKER: Counsel for the Crown.
SP.P:
The witness has spoke of the motion referred to in the declaration. Was there any paper sound in
Mr. Skirving's possession, which was entitled Minutes of the Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There were a number of things found in Mr. Skirving's possession; amongst which, a scroll of the Minutes of the Con∣vention.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Should you know it again?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look at that and see if that is it?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: How are you certain that these are the mi∣nutes of the British Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I can only say, that these are papers which were found in Mr. Skirving's possession, and they were acknowledged to be so by various people, who were examined before me; that is the only reason I have: I did not see them in the Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: There is another question which I hope your Lordships will not think improper. In your office as Sheriff, have you to the best of your judgment acted according to the laws of your country, or have you acted by superior orders?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I certainly would execute no orders, unless I was certain they were according to the laws of my country.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Am I to infer from hence, that you received orders?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: It is not a proper subject of evidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: I put myself under your correction at the time I started the question; however, it may not be amiss that the question was started, though it is not answered.
Joseph Mack sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect being present when Mr. Skirving, the late Secretary of the Convention of the Friends of the People, was brought before the sheriff for examination?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there certain bags of papers brought along with him for inspection?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you present when those bags were opened?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was, when they were put into the inventory, which was very soon after or immediately after they were opened.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was Skirving present?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect among other papers found in this bag, one being found, entitled the Scroll of the Minutes of the Con∣vention?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was it in your hand, that you had an opportunity of ob∣serving it at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I both saw it then, and at Mr. Skirving's house; they were carried in a bag from his house to the sheriff clerk's office, and there entered into an inventory—that is the paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: And you now recognize it as the same?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: (Looks over it) Yes, it is the same.
SP.STAGE: Joseph Mack cross examined by Mr. Margarot.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You act as notary, do you not?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I do not

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Or as clerk to the sheriff?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, writing clerk to the sheriff.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear me protest against the illegality of all the proceedings which had taken place?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: You offered to make a protest, but it was refused to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You are certain that I offered to make one?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: A written one?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not recollect whether it was written or not: I think it is probable it was, but I cannot say—I was not a notary.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: I have objections to that witness, on account of certain expressions of his, and I have a witness now attending to prove those words. I don't know whether that witness should be brought in at present to prove this, or whether it should be kept back till the witnesses for the prosecution are gone through.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: What do you propose to prove?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: That he considered himself as my enemy; these are nearly the words, I look upon myself to be your enemy; or something to that effect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Can you condescend upon any reason, why he should have any enmity to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: I have not the skill of other people; I cannot dive into mens hearts; I find him a very officious time-serving man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: He must answer that question upon oath, whether he has any malice or ill will.
(Sworn.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: Look upon the pannel at the bar; have you any malice or ill-will against that person?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: None at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever say that you were his enemy?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: You may ask him the question again, Mr. Margarot.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: I would wish to have my witness produced in court; it is not my asking him the question merely, Do you not recollect saying one day that you considered yourself as my enemy?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Abercrombie.
SP.P: The court have uniformly laid this down as a rule, that no general charge of a witness making use of an ex∣pression of that nature shall be sufficient to invalidate his testi∣mony, and for this reason, that it would put it in the power of cry witness whatever, if he wished to favour the pannel, to dis∣qualify himself by uttering some vague expression of ill-will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Eskgrove.
SP.P: What are you?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: A messenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Advocate.
SP.P: Did you execute a warrant against the pannel?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Advocate.
SP.P: And against any body else?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; Mr. Gerald.
Q Where was you informed these persons resided?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: At the Black Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were you to take into your custody any papers that you found?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: At what time in the morning was it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: To the best of my knowledge about seven o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Tell the court and jury what passed.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I asked for such gentlemen, I asked for their rooms; the waiter declined shewing me, but told me the number of their rooms; I went into the room where Mr. Gerald and Mr. Mar∣garot were; they were each in separate beds in the same room.
Q Did you tell them you had a warrant against them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; then I went to Mr. Sinclair's room, and locked up all Mr. Margarot's papers, and Mr. Gerald's and Mr. Sinclair's also; Mr. Margarot said he would put his papers into a little trunk, which I did not object to.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he accordingly do so?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He asked Mr. Gerald if he would put his in, upon which he agreed to it, and the papers were put in; and when I was away and came back for them, he said he would not give them me; I said I would take them; he said I might take them at my peril, and I said I should not make any scruple about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the key remain in his possession after the paper was taken away?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, the trunk was locked and he kept the key.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you take the trunk and him with you to the sheriff's?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, and Mr. Gerald.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you present when the trunk was opened and the contents examined?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the pannel agree to open the trunk himself, or was it opened?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The next day when he was before the sheriff, he held the key in his hand; he said he would not give it up, but we might take it from him; upon which the sheriff substitute desired me to take it from him, which I did; the trunk was then opened and inspected.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were those belonging to the pannel distinguished from those belonging to Mr. Gerald?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Each of them claimed separately what belonged to him∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there any inventory made of those papers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you put any mark upon those papers? —A. I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look at those papers deliberately, and see if they are the same?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: (Examines and compares them with the inventory.) Yes, they are the same; they have my initial.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When you went to the Black Bull had you any assistants with you?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, John M'Donald and Neil M'Glashan were both in the room along with me.
SP.STAGE: James Lyon cross examined by Mr. Margarot.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You found us in bed?—A. Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did we show any disposition of resistance, or rather tes∣tify the greatest alacrity to go with you?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: You shewed no disposition to make any resistance; you did not refuse to come along with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did we make you wait long in dressing?—A. No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you shew us the warrants?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, nor you did ask it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did we never ask you to see the warrant?—A. No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did you find the papers in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I found some upon the top of the drawers' head, some in the drawers, and some out in a trunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were the drawers locked?—A. No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was the door of the room locked?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I knocked at the door, and you desired me to come in, and of course I opened the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were the papers in a state of arrangement when you took them off the drawers, and out of the drawers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, by no means.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they not rather confused?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; they were a little confused.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there some in one place, and others in others?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, some I got out of the trunk, and some in the draw∣ers, and some off the drawers.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there papers in more than one drawer?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe there were; I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: But the drawers were not locked?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe not; at least I broke none of them open.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you go along with Mr. Lyon, the messenger, to assist him to execute a warrant against the Pannel at the bar, on the 5th December last?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did you go?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: To the Black Bull, at the head of Leith Walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Tell us, as far as you recollect, what passed upon that occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P:
I went into the house, and stood there till the door was opened; Mr. Lyon went in; he went up the stair, and this gentleman and another were in the bed-room, but had not got their clothes on, and we stood at the door till they were ready;
and Mr. Lyon took what papers he could find, and they were put into a trunk; the trunk was locked, and he put the key in his pocket, and there was a coach at the door; and I took down the trunk, and put in the chaise, and he came along with us, and I got at the back of the chaise, and went to the Sheriff Clerk's Office, and left the trunk at the office.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You have mentioned what passed in the room, and the manner in which the papers were put in the trunk; now, did the Pannel himself put any of the papers in?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, he was helping.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did Mr. Gerald likewise assist to put the papers in the trunk?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; Mr. Gerald's papers were put in first, and then Mr. Margarot's, and then the trunk was locked and carried to the Sheriff Clerk's Office.
SP.STAGE: John Macdonald, cross examined by Mr. Margarot.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Could you at that time discriminate which were my pa∣pers and which were those of Mr. Gerald?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I can neither tell which were yours, nor which were his; but, it is my opinion, your's were put in first.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were the drawers locked?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You did not see a key in those drawers?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was the room door locked?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, it was open when I came in; you was apprehended, I dare say, before I came in.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were the papers put into the trunk tied up in parcels or loosely?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Some were tied up, and some were loose.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did we tie up any of them before you

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not see any string tied on them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who took them out of the drawers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Mr. Lyon took them out.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect the reason why Mr. Lyon would not shew me the warrant?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: You did not insist upon shewing it much.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he shew it? and remember you are upon your oath.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You well recollect that I asked him to produce it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: And you are not certain that he did shew it?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: But you perfectly recollect that I asked him to shew it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: Have you any objection to this witness?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: No, my Lord, he looks honest. (Sworn).

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you a member of any of the Societies of Friends of the People?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you a Delegate from that society to the British Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I was a member of both.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you attend regularly their meeting?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: My business did not allow me a regular attendance, but I attended as often as I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect, during your attendance at those meet∣ings, whether there was any subdivision, any smaller meetings that the Convention was divided into?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What were they called?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The first name they got, was Divisions; but they were afterwards called Sections.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What terms did the members of the Convention gene∣rally address each other by?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The terms were different; but the general term was, Citizen.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect that you had different Committees ap∣pointed in that Convention for the forwarding of business?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect several Committees.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: But some?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have heard some mentioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: And what were they called?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: That that I recollect most, at present, was the Committee of Union.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever hear of a Committee of Secrecy?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: A Convention of Emergency?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect the hearing of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect hearing the term organization men∣tioned? —

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had you primary assemblies to refer to?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How were your meetings called?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It was generally called the British Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: But when you met on a particular night, and talked about it the next day, what name did you give it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The British Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever use the name of sittings?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, frequently.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You say you attended as often as your business permitted?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Have you had occasion to see the pannel there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, frequently.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever see him act as Preses or Chairman at these meetings?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever hear him move any resolutions at these meetings, of any kind?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have very frequently heard Mr. Margarot speak; but unless some particular resolution be mentioned, I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect at any time, any motion or proposal for a Committee of Union?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; I was not present then.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect his having delivered a speech, at any of the meetings you have attended, that had any relation to a Convention Bill?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: With any reference to such a bill as had passed in Ireland?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No:

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Solicitor General.
SP.P: Do you remember a motion being made by Mr. Calendar?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing what it was about?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I remember one of the motions, about the people meet∣ing in defence of their liberties, in case of any bill being brought into Parliament, similar to a Convention Bill in Ireland against the Constitution of the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What did Mr. Calendar propose that your Convention should do in that case?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I recollect a motion of that import being introduced, and that Mr. Calendar acknowledged the motion as his; but as to any thing relative to that motion, I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you present when the motion was made?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There was a rule in the Convention, that no motion should be discussed the same night on which it was made; I was pre∣sent when it was brought in by Mr. Calendar.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was it that Mr. Calendar proposed should be done in case such a bill should be brought into the British Par∣liament?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Margarot.
SP.P: I object to that question, as it respects Mr. Calendar, and not me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Solicitor General.
SP.P: It is charged in the indictment against this very pannel; and, therefore, I will repeat the question. What was it that Mr. Calendar proposed should be done, in case it should be brought into the British Parliament?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: That the people should meet to assert their right, so far as I recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there any debate upon it that night?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It is a rule that there shall be no debate when a question is proposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you present when it was discussed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not when it was discussed in that shape in which Mr. Callendar introduced it; but I was when it was amended: so far as I recollect, the spirit of Mr. Calendar's motion was retained; but it was very much extended: there was a proposal of what, in certain events, should take place. I don't clearly remember the circumstances about it; but it was a motion for a Secret Com∣mittee, in case those events should take place.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was it proposed that the Convention should assemble in certain events?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, it was, that they should meet in a certain place, in certain events.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Now, be so good as tell us what those events were, as far as you remember them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The one already named, was that of a bill being brought into Parliament similar to the Convention Bill in Ireland; as to the other, I cannot remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was any thing said about the suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think there was.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there any thing said about the repeal of the Scotch Act, 1701, of wrongous imprisonment?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was any thing said in case of an invasion of foreign troops?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think I remember that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was any place fixed upon for the meetings? how was that determined upon?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There was a motion that a place should be fixed upon by a Secret Committee; they were to find out a way of letting the Delegates know of it.
Q Was it not to be published?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was it to be told them immediately, or only told them when that emergency should happen?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There was a mention of a sealed letter to be given to each Delegate.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who made this motion with respect to the place of meet∣ing?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Read that paper.

"Citizen Margarot proposed the following motion: That a Secret Committee of three, with the Secretary, be appointed to determine the place where such Convention of Emergency shall meet; and such place shall remain a secret with them, and with the Secretary of this Convention; and, that the Delegates shall, at the breaking up of the present session, be entrusted with a sealed letter, containing the name of the place of meeting. This letter shall be delivered unopened to their constituents; the receipt of which shall be acknowledged by a letter to the Secre∣tary, preserved in the same state, until the period shall arive at which it shall be deemed necessary for the Delegates to set off. This motion was seconded by Citizen Moffat."

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Is that the motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: To the best of my recollection there was a motion of a similar import to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know who were the Members of this Secret Committee?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I recollect some of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was Mr. Margarot one of them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: To the best of my recollection, he was one of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember Mr. Margarot making any speech to the Convention before he had made his motion?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember his saying any thing at all about its being a tocsin?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You remember that the case of the Convention Bill was one of the cases of emergency?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: And of the suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I heard that mentioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You also recollect something about an invasion being mentioned?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any proposal during the time you attended this meeting, that this Convention should act in case they should be dispersed?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who made that motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not recollect at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you think Mr. Margarot made a motion of that kind?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It runs in my mind that he did; but I cannot swear that it was him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear Mr. Margarot make any speech that had a reference to that case?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think I recollect something of Mr. Margarot speaking as to the propriety of such a thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you sure?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot be particular; but there is a conceit in my mind that he did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember Mr. Sinclair making a motion of that kind?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing particular about the passing of that?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: So far as my recollection serves me, we were pretty una∣nimous.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect all the Convention standing up at the time they passed it?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; I think I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did it contain any particular expressions of their declar∣ing before God and the world that they would do so and so? Do you recollect that that made a part of the motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Certainly these words were mentioned, but I am not cer∣tain whether it was the decided resolution of the Convention or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember whether this motion, or the resolution of the Convention, bore any thing that they declared before God and the world that we should follow the wholesome ex∣ample of former times?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say; I don't remember it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did it say any thing about paying no attention to a Con∣vention Bill if it should be passed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P:
I think there was a mention of something similar to this, but whether it was made a part of the final resolution of the
Committee, I cannot tell: there was a great deal of loose ex∣pressions made use of.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any thing said in the Convention about burning that resolution of Sinclair's?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I heard nothing of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any thing said about burning any of the other motions?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect; they seemed, to be confident of what they were doing, and were not acting, under the apprehension of fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there any thing said about destroying or not insert∣ing it in the minutes?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: At the time this Secret Committee was appointed, was there any opposition made to it?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect.
SP.STAGE: Thomas Coburn cross examined by Mr. Margarot.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: It seems you are a member of the British Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What is your profession?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: My profession is partly a manufacturer in the weaving line, and partly a merchant.
Q Do you pay any taxes?—I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you find these taxes heavy?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have very often thought them very heavy.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You are a member of the Friends of the People?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was your reason for joining the Friends of the People?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The reason was, a thorough conviction of the necessity of a Reform in the British House of Commons.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was your reason of accepting the office of delegate in the British Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: It was to help forward that great and grand object that so forcibly struck my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you mean to help it forward by legal means or force of arms?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Force of arms was never mentioned in the Convention, and it is the last thing that I should wish, to see a drop of blood spilt in the cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: In the British Convention did you ever see any tendency to have recourse to open force?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It was diametrically opposite to my views to have the least recourse to open force, nor was it the subject of discussion in the Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Have you heard of a committee of Union?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was to be the purport of that Committee of Union?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P:
So far as I recollect, the design of that Committee was to draw up regulations, by which the people of England and Scot∣land,
of the same sentiments, might join in their endeavours to obtain that object.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You have heard of a Convention of Secrecy likewise?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Of a Committee of Secrecy I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Have you ever seen it customary in any Clubs, if you ever belonged to any, that there should be a certain degree of trust reposed in a small number of confidential men, who should form a Committee and retain some secrets to themselves, not to be divulged to the world? Have you ever witnessed any such thing, or does it strike you as an unprecedented thing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: So far from striking me as an unprecedented thing, that it strikes me upon many occasions as a necessary thing, pruden∣tially to keep secrets of every society when it is necessary for their interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Have you ever heard of a Committee of Organization in the Convention?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I think I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was the drift of that Committee of Organization?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: What I conceive to be the direct design of the Committee was to form rules, by which the Convention might regulate themselves in their present and in their subsequent meetings, if they should see occasion for any.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you think that the Committee of Organization did not likewise refer to the internal regulation of the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: As I meant to express in my last answer, I considered the committee of Organization to refer chiefly to the internal af∣fairs of the Convention, and with respect to future Conven∣tions, if there should be such.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: It seems that you have heard that meetings of the Con∣vention were at times called sittings; do you imagine that that expression was adopted as borrowed from a neighbouring country, or that is was an expression which followed of course, and to which we are thoroughly accustomed in the English lan∣guage?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: However the reading of newspapers might lead us to make use of terms, I cannot say; but it was certainly a word that it was very natural to make use of.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You have seen me act as Preses?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: That word is Latin, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I am very little acquainted with Latin▪ I meant President.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You are sufficiently acquainted with it to know that at present Rome is the seat of the Pope, are you not?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: We have no doubt of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Consequently if there is any criminality in adopting a French word, do you think there is not an equal criminality in using a Latin one▪

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: These things appeared to me to be so trifling, that I did not think it worth my while to make any objection to them: some were of French origin, and some of British, and some of La∣tin; but I did not think it worth while to make any objection to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You have heard of a motion proposed by Mr. Callender; you were present when it was originally moved, that the peo∣ple should meet to assert their rights in the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Assert their rights, were the words, to the best of my re∣collection.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What do you understand by a Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: What I understand by a Convention is a meeting of men for any purpose that they propose.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are the men who meet in Convention supposed to be de∣legated by a larger body of men?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot pretend a particular disquisition of these points, but it strikes me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: By the word Convention, and meeting in Convention, did you understand a peaceable assembly of men assembled to deliberate, or did you understand by it, an assembly of men going to adopt violent measures, and to carry them into execu∣tion themselves?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: What I understand by Convention was, that they met with a sincere and hearty design to promote the good of the country, by a thorough reform in the British House of Commons, and that they meant to do this by peaceable means.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you imagine there are sufficient abuses at present in the legislature of this kingdom, to legalize our attempting to address them by petition, or any form that might be legal and constitutional?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have already said that I am deeply impressed with the idea of the necessity of it: I see the most glaring abuses in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you imagine that if a Convention Bill was to be passed, or was even to be brought into the House of Commons, that it would not shew a disposition in the House of Commons to extend their privileges, and to encroach upon our rights?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Such a Bill has always struck me as sapping the very foun∣dations of Civil Liberty; and, indeed going beyond the power of the legislators themselves, to deprive the people of their na∣tural rights.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You say it is your opinion that there are already suffi∣cient grounds for the good people of this country to demand a Reform in Parliament; do you think those grounds would not be increased by two such events as the bringing in of a Conven∣tion Bill, or a motion for suspending the Habeas Corpus act, which is one of the greatest privileges a subject of Britain en∣joys, or the Bill for preventing wrongous imprisonment; do you think that would not make a very considerable addition to our complaints?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I am satisfied in my own mind, that it would increase the grievances of the people, and be like a grave stone to their li∣berties.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: In what light did you look upon the members of the Bri∣tish Convention? Did you look upon them as a turbulent set of vagabonds, or did you look upon them as a body of men dele∣gated by some of their fellow subjects for a certain purpose, and that these men so delegated were industrious, peaceable, cre∣ditable men?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Their design, I have to reason no call in question, was the good of their country: as to characters, there is always a mixture in all assemblies; but I believe, taking the whole toge∣ther, there was a great degree of respectability with respect to characters.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Then they did not appear to you to come under the description of swine, rabble, or wretches?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: As the friends of their country, I believe not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When is the properest time for men to assemble and de∣liberate? It in time of danger, or prosperity? It appears that the Convention was to assemble in this manner, in the moment that an invasion of foreign troops should take place in Great Britain. Do you conceive that to be a time of danger, and call∣ing for the attention of all Britons throughout the island; or do you think it a time for them to sit idle and suffer themselves to be enslaved by a foreign power?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think it is high time that a Reform had taken place, as it ought to have done long since.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When you have any thing that interests you very much, do you publish it all through your house, and different parts of your family, or sometimes keep a secret to yourself in your pri∣vate affairs?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, no doubt; and every person endued with any de∣gree of prudence will find occasion to keep their secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: If you had a particular piece of business to do, and that you was apprehensive that a superior power, inimical to your design and to your welfare, would prevent you from doing that particular business at such a place, would you inform that inimi∣cal power where you was to meet to do that business?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I should certainly do every thing in my power, from com∣mon prudence, to keep it from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When you send a letter by the post to a friend do you ever attach any degree of criminality to sealing that letter till he gets into the country, especially if you wish the contents not to be known to him till a certain period?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Can you discover any thing of a seditious nature in a Con∣vention standing up to pass a resolution?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P:
I find here something which I don't know, whether it is thoroughly assented to by you, that there was a declaration be∣fore God and the world, that they would follow the wholesome
example of their forefathers; what is the characteristic of Bri∣tons?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: That they are strongly attached to the cause of li∣berty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How came we by the Revolution? was it by any exertion of our forefathers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It no doubt was.
Q How came we by the Magna Charta?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: So far as I understand the subject, it was entirely by the same means.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did your forefathers do wrong in so exerting themselves?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: My opinion is that they did not do enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you think it impossible for a House of Commons to do an unconstitutional act?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There has been many things done in the House of Com∣mons which I sincerely regret.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: We had originally Parliaments, or some time back, Par∣liaments of three years; now by an Act of Parliament they are lengthened to seven years; suppose another Act should make them during life, and a third Act should make them hereditary, do you imagine that would be an unconstitutional act?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It has always struck me as a thing beyond their power to alter or destroy the fundamental rights of the people, or any thing that would extend their own power.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you imagine that the power originates with the peo∣ple?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do so.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you imagine it to be either in the Bill of Rights, or the claim of rights, expressed, that the people should be at li∣berty to meet to communicate to each other their grievances, and plan methods for obtaining redress?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have often wished to see the Bill of Rights, the Habeas Corpus Act, and all those things; but I have never had it in my power; but in my opinion, the object of all government is the good of the people, and that the liberties of the people ought to be carefully guarded by them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: It appears by what has passed here, that the Convention had some notion of a God: did they ever pray in their meetings?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever see any disorderly behaviour there? were they riotous or tumultuous?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Considering their numbers, they were free of that beyond many meetings that I have seen of the same number: I saw no riotous meetings: there were sometimes disputes, but no riots.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: As to the burning of the motion, you said they were not acting under the apprehension of fear: did you suppose they could justify their proceedings?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I always considered, that in the Convention the Members that had occasion to speak, always spoke freely, believing that they had nothing essentially secret to keep to themselves, but that their great object was the good of their country.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever discover in the Convention or in the mem∣bers of it, either in or out of the Convention, any propensity to sedition, treason, or rebellion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have always said, that as far as I could discover the de∣sign of the Convention, it was to obtain a thorough Reform in the British House of Commons, by peaceable and legal means.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Alexander Aitcheson
SP.P: sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Henderland.
SP.P: Have you any malice or ill-will against the pannel at the bar?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It is impossible I should, my Lord: on the contrary, I es∣teem him a second Sydney.—I am very much obliged to the pub∣lic prosecutor, on account of my family, otherwise, I would much sooner appear here as the pannel at your Lordships' bar, than as a witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Counsel for the Crown.
SP.P: Were you a Member of the British Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; of all the three Conventions I had the honour to be a Delegate from the Canongate Society; the Delegates, consi∣dering themselves as Delegates for six months, adjourned their meeting; but upon account of the coming down of the English Delegates, they resumed it again.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: That was in November last.—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who were the English Delegates?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There were four or five of them; there was Citizen Margarot, Citizen Sinclair, Citizen Gerald from London, and Citizen Brown from Sheffield.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Now did you act as secretary or assistant secretary?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; assistant secretary.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there a scroll of minutes drawn up?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look at that, and see if any part of it is your hand-writ∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; a very great part of it; but there were some others who wrote.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who were they?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: George Ross, and afterwards the Convention appointed three assistants daily.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who is George Ross?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Clerk in the Gazetteer Office.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: This scroll of minutes, did they contain, to far as you could judge, a fair and distinct account of what happened in the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P:
To the best of my knowledge and belief they did; I should have been guilty of palming falshood upon the public and
the Convention if they did not: but there may have been mis∣takes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they corrected the day after they were made out?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: By no means: they were postponed till a future day, till a committee should be appointed to revise them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was Mr. Margarot present at these meetings commonly?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: As far as I observed he was a regular attendant.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was he sometimes Chairman at the meetings?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Once he certainly was.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look at that: whose hand-writing is it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It is mine (reads it). Citizen Margarot moved that a Committtee be appointed to consider of the means, and draw up the outlines of a proper plan for a general union between the two nations, as before proposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did Mr. Margarot make that motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He certainly did, or I should not have minuted it down: a simple fact like that I cannot be mistaken in; but in a speech, viva voce, I might have made a mistake (reads it again); and give me leave to add, I expected from Mr. Margarot's abilities and the spirit of the times, a more perfect system than was made up by a sycophant faction in the reign of queen Anne.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look at that.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: (Reads.) Citizen A. Callendar moved, That in case the Minister bring into the Commons' House a motion for a Conven∣tion Bill, it shall be noticed immediately to the Delegates. The words shall be noticed immediately to the Delegates, are in my hand-writing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any discussion in the Convention upon that motion; particularly, did Mr. Margarot speak upon the occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Indeed my memory is so treacherous that I cannot recol∣lect any thing, especially when I am taking notes: if I don't write at all, I remember tolerably well the chief facts, but if I do write, I recollect nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there any thing said about that event being a tocsin to the friends of liberty?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I never heard the word tocsin mentioned in the Conven∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any amendment or alteration upon Mr. Callendar's motion, or if it gave rise to any other motion in the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Such things may have happened, but I cannot recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know of a motion being-made by Mr. Sinclair in consequence of, and following up Mr. Callendar's motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was absent a variety of nights, when I wished to be pre∣sent, but particular business kept me away.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: But did you hear Mr. Margarot make any motion in con∣sequence of Mr. Callendar's?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible that I can say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did Mr. Sinclair make any motion about the Convention meeting on certain events?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; there was a motion made, at least I understood so. I came in one evening pretty late, and Mr. Sinclair, or some person, had made a motion, and as soon as I had taken my seat, Mr. Sinclair made a motion, that something that had passed be∣fore should be burned, and I was surprised, and got up and op∣posed it, and was seconded—upon the ground, that as every thing we had done before was open to the public, we should do nothing secret, and therefore the motion was not carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did that motion relate to the Delegates' meeting?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was surprised and alarmed at any thing being secret; but when I understood that nothing more was meant by it than merely concealing the place where they were to meet, I thought there was nothing at all in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Justice Clerk.
SP.P: Did you hear any thing of a Committee of Secrecy?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I enquired next day, and was told the nature of it, that it was merely to conceal the intended place of meeting, in case of opposition, and in case of necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any thing about the Convention of Emer∣gency at all in the meeting?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; at the sections and among our friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Read that.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: (Reads from the minutes.) Citizen Margarot read and proposed the following motion: That a Secret Committee of three, and the Secretary, be appointed to determine the place where such Convention of Emergency shall meet; and such place shall remain a secret with them and the Secretary of this Con∣vention, and that each Delegate shall, at the breaking up of the present session, be entrusted with a sealed letter, containing the name of the place of the meeting; this letter shall be delivered unopened to his constituents, the receipt of which shall be ac∣knowledged by a letter to the Secretary, preserved in the same state, until the period shall arrive at which it shall be deemed necessary for the Delegates to set off; this motion was seconded by Citizen Moffat: the greater part of that is my own hand-writing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You see mention is there made of a Convention of Emer∣gency: now I want to know, as far as you recollect, the cases in which they were to meet?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: As far as I recollect, they were to meet in case a motion was made in Parliament to bring in a bill similar to that passed in Ireland, to prevent our having any meetings.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was one of the cases the suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was the case of an invasion of foreign troops mentioned?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect any other case of Emergency in which the Convention were to meet?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there another case, if any attempt should be made to disperse the Convention? was that a case in which they were to meet?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say that I recollect that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you in the Convention the evening before the ap∣prehension of Mr. Margarot and Skirving, and the other per∣sons?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I might, very possibly; but I don't recollect I was pre∣sent that evening after they had been apprehended in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: But do you recollect whether you was in the Conven∣tion the preceding evening?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot charge my memory with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look at that?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The whole of that is written by another person (reads from the Minutes). Citizen Margarot begs leave to bring in a motion, to the effect, that the moment of any illegal dispersion of the present Convention shall be considered as a summons to the Delegates to repair to the place of meeting appointed for the Convention of Emergency by the Secret Committee; that the Secret Committee is instructed to proceed, without delay, to fix the place of meeting; and that the same motion be consider∣ed next evening; which was accordingly granted. My Lords, I observe, from the whole of this being written by another per∣son, that I was not present at all that evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Advocate.
SP.P: Look at the first of these papers, Num∣ber 3. of the general inventory, and tell me if you ever saw it before?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: (Reads from the Minutes a motion for a union between the two kingdoms, to demand the restoration of their rights.) I think it is a most excellent motion, my Lord, and am very sorry it was not followed up.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Advocate.
SP.P: I did not ask you for your opinion, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: My Lords, I beg to say, this persecution, and all of them, are for opinions; and I must, before God, in justice to my coun∣try, declare, that it is for opinions as well as facts.
Gentlemen of the Jury, 'Tis a prosecution for opinions.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look at that paper which has your mark upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It has, but it is not my writing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did you receive it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: From the Convention; I remember reading it from the beginning to the end.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who is James Gartley?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He was Delegate from Glasgow.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Is it your hand-writing upon the back of it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had you an opportunity of seeing the newspapers in which the proceedings of the Convention were published to the world?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I had an opportunity; but was so extremely hurried at that time with my own business, and that of the Convention, that I could not read them, but laid them by to be a treasure of entertainment at some future time; for four weeks, at that time, I did not read a single article in the Gazetteer.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Have you read them since?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Only in the Sheriff Clerk's Chamber; and that seemed to contain a very accurate account.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: And corresponded with the Minutes you yourself had taken?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.
SP.STAGE: Alexander Aitcheson cross examined by Mr. Margarot.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You was a member of the British Convention?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you, prior to that, a Member of the Friends of the People?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, long prior.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was your motive for associating with the Friends of the People?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The public good, which I hope I will always have at heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What do you understand by the public good.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I understand, by the public good, that grievances should be redressed, and every man made as happy as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had you any specific plan?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, we had just two objects; these two objects were, a shorter duration of Parliaments, and a more frequent election of Representatives; because we considered the length of parlia∣ments, and the slow return of elections, to be the two great and fundamental causes of all the grievances which the nation labours under.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What sort of men were these with whom you associated, the Friends of the People? I don't particularly mean what class, high or low, rich or poor; but what morals, what temper, what behaviour; in short, what opinion do you form of them in ge∣neral?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I considered them to be a good, moral, respectable set of people; not respectable in point of riches, but in that respect which will be looked at by the all-seeing-eye of the Almighty; respectable in point of morals.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did they ever shew any disposition to treason, sedition, or felony?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not that I ever saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you delegated by a Society of the Friends of the People to the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was some time.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the other Members of the Convention represent a number of men from here?—A Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did it appear to you, that the Convention adhered to the spirit of reform which was set on foot by the Friends of the People?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They certainly did, to the best of my ideas; and even when they followed up the primary idea of shorter duration of Parliaments, and more frequent elections, and adopted the idea of universal suffrage and annual Parliaments, they went cer∣tainly no further than the Duke of Richmond and Mr. Pitt had gone before.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You must take care not to mention the word primary, be∣cause it may inculpate me further; for that is one word that is charged against me.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I consider all words in our Dictionary lawful to be used; and it is a dreadful crisis that we are come to, if a man is to be criminated for a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You spoke of the English Delegates; you don't mean that they represented the people of England?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Certainly, only those who sent them; I understood that Mr. Margarot and Mr. Sinclair represented about 5000 people, and Mr. Brown about 5000 from Sheffield.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You have not positivey sworn to the entire scroll of Mi∣nutes shewn to you; some part of it you don't acknowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I can only swear to that that was wrote by myself; and so far as my ideas led me to think, I was right in writing them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Though the name of Minutes is given to them, are they, in fact, the Minutes of the Convention till they have received the revisal of the Committee?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Certainly not; to correct and to expunge all errors what∣ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they ever offered, or sent forth to the world by way of publication?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they ever corrected by authority of the Conven∣tion?
A I never heard of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are there any erasures, any interlineations in them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Several emendations were made upon the motions of one or two Members; but when several emendation were proposed, it was said, you may leave that to the Committee.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: To the best of your recollection (I made a motion about the union of the two kingdoms), did it appear to you that that motion had a seditious tendency?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: On the contrary, I conceive it would be for the good of mankind, and the salvation of these kingdoms.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you look upon tocsin to be a French word?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I suppose so: but I cannot say that it is: I never heard it made use of in the Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you sure that it is not instead of one French word, two Chinese words?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say; I know nothing about the Chinese.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: I have a notion 'tis; then, all the knowledge you gained of a Secret Committee, was the next day among the Sections, and among the Friends?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: That reminds me of a mistake I made before; for I find that I have recorded that very motion which Mr. Sinclair moved to be burnt, and which was afterwards agreed not to be burnt; and I heard further of the business next day.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: There was a motion made for a Convention of Emergen∣cy; did the Convention ever fix upon or delineate the plan by which they were to act, or did that Convention ever take place?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: In joining the Friends of the People, and in joining the British Convention, for the purpose of obtaining a reform, did you think yourselves warranted by the Constitution to endea∣vour to obtain a redress of grievances?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Perfectly; and I would think so still, if I were to be sent to Botany Bay for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are those grievances done away?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: By no means; and I am sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you of opinion, that if a Convention Bill was passed in the British Parliament, it would tend to lessen those grievances.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It would extend them tenfold.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What would be the consequence of the suspension of the Habeas Corpus act, and of the Act for preventing wrongous imprisonment?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It would be certainly a great encroachment upon the pri∣vilege of Britons.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Might not every peaceable inhabitant of these realms run great danger, in case of a foreign invasion, of losing his property, by the enemies plundering him of it, if they were successful?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have no doubt of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you think it would be more constitutional in English∣men, more constitutional in Scotchmen, more constitutional in Britons, to sit idle and look at a foreign invasion, or attend a Convention of Emergency.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I dare say the whole Court, and all the audience will a∣gree, that to meet upon such an occasion, would be a work of necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was foreign invasion the expression that was made use of, or was a French invasion ever mentioned?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: As far as I recollect, French invasion was mentioned in some person's motion; but I cannot say in whose motion, or whether it was in doors, or out of doors; or in the Conven∣tion, or out of the Convention, I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Then you mean to say, that an Invasion from France was uppermost in the minds of the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say what was uppermost; but I know I have heard that expression, but I believe it was out of the Convention.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was it customary for the motions to be handed to the table, which were not passed in the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Many such were handed in, and many not passed, and not taken notice of at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you certain, that the two motions shewn you just now, and which were indorsed by you, and, I presume, were given into you in that manner, are you sure they were ever read in the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Be so good as shew me them again (looks at them). One of these motions is certainly new to me since I came before the Court: a person might say to me, there is a question concerning union, and I might indorse it so without ever reading it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was the mode of proceeding in opening and closing the business of the day?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: As the business of all Christian people should be, it was begun and ended by prayer.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever observe any thing of a seditious or riotous appearance in the Convention?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not in the least.
Did you ever hear any thing mentioned, or whispered in the Convention, that might tend to overturn the Constitution?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever hear any thing mentioned there against the King?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever hear any thing mentioned there against place-men and pensioners?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Often.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: That, I suppose, is the Sedition that is meant to be charg∣ed.

SP.SPEAKER: Witness.
SP.P: I thought it very hard that the Lord Advocate, when I was here before, should charge me with falshood. I hope he will not do so now.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What profession are you of?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Clerk in the Gazetteer office.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How long have you been in that profession?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Seven or eight years.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you a Member of the meeting of the Friends of the People?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you a Member of the British Convention?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Delegate from what society?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: From the Canongate Society.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you act in any particular office in the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I sometimes acted as Assistant Secretary?

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who else assisted the Secretary?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Several persons.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there any persons who wrote short-hand and took down the debates?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look at these Minutes, and see if you can find your own hand-writing?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you take down, to the best of your abilities, what did really pass in the Convention?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I certainly would take nothing down that I thought im∣proper.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: And you would take down nothing but what passed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect, if it was the practice at the commence∣ment of the meeting, to read over the scroll of the Minutes?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have seen it done sometimes, and sometimes not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect whether it was ever usual to correct them upon reading them over?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think, I recollect one night, there were some corrections.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you acquainted with that Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have had the honour to see Mr. Margarot many times, and been in his company.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was he a Member of the Convention?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Have you heard him speak?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I have heard him propose motions.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you ever see him act as Chairman?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot recollect to a certainty, whether he was or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect any motion in the Convention with res∣pect to a union between England and Scotland?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I recollect the union with the Societies of the Friends of the People in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Read that?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: (Reads). Margarot moved, that a committee be appointed to consider.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Whose hand-writing is it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe it is Mr. Aitcheson's.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You recollect there was such a motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, that there was a union to take place between the English societies and the Scotch.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any motion being made of a Conven∣tion of Emergency?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing about the purpose of that Convention; of the events in which they were to meet?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: To remonstrate to Parliament against a Bill, such as a Convention Bill.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there any particular persons who made a motion respecting it?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe it was made by Mr. Callendar.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect that that motion was made?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: A. Yes it is my hand-writing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember the events that were to happen.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: That, in case of a Convention Bill, they were to meet in order to draw up a remonstrance to Parliament.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was any other event mentioned? any thing about the Habeas Corpus Act?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't at present recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect any thing about a foreign invasion, or any thing about foreign troops?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, about the Hessians and Hanoverians being brought over.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You spoke about Mr. Callendar's motion: when was it taken up? the next day?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was the Convention used to take notice of the motions at the time they were made, or did they lie over?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They generally laid over.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was that motion of Mr. Callendar's taken up afterwards?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there any debate about Mr. Callendar's motion res∣pecting the Convention Bill? and recollect yourself before you give an answer?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot be particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there any amendments proposed to that motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe there were.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What resolution was come to in consequence of the amendment?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't know particularly; I don't recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Is that your writing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, (reads). Citizen Sinclair read the amendments upon Citizen Callendar's motion; and then there comes some other person's writing; and, it was agreed, that the house should re∣solve itself into a Committee, to consider of the amendments proposed; the Convention being resumed, and the amendments being read over, the members stood upon their legs, and so∣lemnly and unanimously passed the following resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Now recollect yourself, and tell us what passed at that time. Was it a resolution upon Citizen Callendar's motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Now recollect what that motion was?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look if it is mentioned there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, there is a blank page follows it. The resolution then passed, was reserved to be entered 'till the end of the Minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Advocate.
SP.P: It is very material that the Jury should take down these words; for it is that upon which I shall found a very material part of what I shall have to say to them. Repeat it again.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think the Resolution that was then passed, was left to be entered at the last part of the Minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Look, and see if you find any more blanks?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe there are not (looks over the Minutes). Yes, here is a blank of four lines.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any proposal being made about burn∣ing any part of the written evidence, or destroying any motion or resolution the Convention had come to?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I don't recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know Mr. Aitcheson?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect any objection being made by him to burning or destroying any resolution that they might have come to?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I do not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you recollect any other person, a Member of that Convention, objecting to that measure?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not recollect any such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Burnet.
SP.P: Do you remember a motion being made for a Secret Committee?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Solicitor General.
SP.P: Who was it that proposed that motion, which passed solemnly and unanimously?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the members all stand up when that motion passed so solemnly?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I don't recollect; but I should suppose so, from what is written here.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing about declaring before God and the world, any thing?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing that was said about calami∣tous circumstances?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; there was a resolution in case of a Convention Bill.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing about paying no regard to such an act if it passed?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I never would agree to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any speech or motion being made as to what the Convention were to do, upon the meeting being dis∣persed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: If they were dispered they were to meet in another place.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who was it that spoke with regard to that; did Mr. Mar∣garot say any thing, or make a speech upon that subject? recol∣lect yourself?—

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was is debated? Was there any difference of opinion upon that subject?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember any motion being made with regard to it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe there was.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was it Mr. Margarot that made the motion?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
